Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Expectation2: Maintain passenger safety and provide assistance during service.
Situation2: The passenger emergency alarm has been activated due to a medical emergency in the train.
Story:
I was sitting at the dinner table, fork in hand, as my stepbrother animatedly described his idea for a family hiking trip this weekend. My stepmom looked at me, her eyes hopeful, and I knew she wanted me to join in, to be part of the family, to say yes. I nodded along, trying to seem engaged, but my phone buzzed in my pocket. I glanced at the screen—my shift as a subway operator was about to start. I barely had time to change before heading out.

Later, as I guided the train through the tunnels, my mind drifted back to the dinner table and the laughter I’d left behind. Suddenly, the emergency alarm blared. A passenger was in distress. My training kicked in: I had to stop the train, alert emergency services, and keep everyone calm. But as I reached for the intercom, my phone vibrated again—a family group chat, my stepbrother asking if I could make it for the hike. I felt torn, the weight of my responsibility to the passengers pressing down on me, while the hope of my new family tugged at my heart.
